[h1]The gist of it:[/h1]
Had no idea what to expect going in blind with Pacific Drive, but I do enjoy taking risks sometimes with certain purchases, and it's safe to say that this was quite an enjoyable ride.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Essentially, you're a dude who ends up stuck in a post-apocalyptic zone filled with tons of deadly anomalies, and your only hope is the car you're driving, which is also a supernatural object. You'll meet some characters over the radio that have lived most of their lives in the Pacific zone, and they'll try to help you survive and escape the area while also uncovering some of its mysteries. 

There's a lot of lore to find regarding all anomalies and the zone itself, but a lot of things never get properly explained, and the ending is quite unsatisfactory. It is understandable considering the mystery genre; however, there's a difference between leaving things ambiguous and just ending it for the sake of ending it. I don't think the game does a good job at making you "think" about the zone. As I explored, I just wished I would uncover some super secret entity, anything really, but nothing truly mind-blowing ever happens. The DLC isn't that great in explaining things; it just adds a plot about a certain character and their past, and that is it. 

Story rating: 7/10

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The gameplay is essentially a survival game, similar to others such as Subnautica and whatnot, except the survivor is the car. The car is your life, and you must treat it exceptionally well. You'll have a ton of upgrades for it from the engine and its chassis to its wheels. The loop involves going on a run through several areas, looting all sorts of parts, and then escaping/surviving back to your main base. This loop can be endless if you wish, however, you can also just follow through the main story. 

Exploration is a big aspect of the game, and you'll encounter a ton of anomalies that will make your life worse, and sometimes better. These anomalies can range from shocking traps to blocks of concrete falling from the sky. For the most part, it's a chill game as long as you loot and upgrade your car accordingly. Very rarely did I feel in danger, and I did not play on the standard difficulty that the game launched with, but instead I picked a harder one, which increased the anomalies and whatnot. 

Loot, upgrade, repeat, the end. If you don't like driving, then this game is certainly not for you. You'll be walking 20% of the game at best. I would not recommend getting the DLC as it does its own thing, and you'll probably get bored with its annoying new mechanic loop. 

Gameplay rating: 8/10

[h1]Audio[/h1]
Voice acting is great, and all the characters that talk through the radio do a fantastic job at immersing you into their world. The music is licensed stuff, I think, but overall it fits well, and it is quite enjoyable to listen to, whether exploring or in your garage. 

As for the sound effects, they're all pretty good as well, and a big part of making the game's atmosphere shine. In fact, I absolutely recommend you boost them when exploring, it'll creep you out a lot of times. 

Audio rating: 8/10

[h1]Graphics, performance and tech analysis[/h1]
Optimization is not that great, and the game is not exactly a demanding looker. It looks like your standard UE indie game, colorful, varied, and whatnot. The atmosphere is fantastic, though for the first hours when you have no idea what to expect. It's eerie and at times might even scare you a bit. It's a shame its consistency falters around mid-game towards the end, when there really isn't anything unexpected aside from new anomalies to encounter. 

Haven't had any major bugs, and for the most part, it was stutter-free. 

Graphics, performance, and tech analysis score: 8/10

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
It's a pretty good game, it doesn't do anything better than other survival games, but it's a safe bet if you're into the genre and love driving around. 

[h1]Final score: 7.7/10[/h1]

This is so hard to rate. I'm probably done playing it, however, I'm rating it with charity as, if you're okay with the things I point out I think you'll love the game.

First, the format of the game. I don't mind the excursions based missions, BUT it would have been so much better as either a small open world, or, simpler and just as satisfying being done in a "road trip" format. Remove the home base. The car is the home base. This is what I expected from the game. The home base really tanked the vibe for me. Perfect vibe would have been to find a safe place to stop each leg of the journey through this place, set up your radio and your tools, and work on the car.

Second. The actual repairs are hit and miss. I love how simulation based it is, forcing you to do things step by step and creating a connection to the car, but I think they were too afraid to commit. I want more. Slapping putty on everything for repairs? Blah. I would have been pumped to remove the tire, apply patches, put tire back on, etc. 

The driving is also simulation based, and I think hits exactly the right level of detail to fun ratio.

Now to the biggest miss for me. Looting is painful. it has such potential, but it ends up being a massive grind almost immediately. I want to find things that make me excited. I don't want to repeatedly discover garbage represented by base icons. Oh look, my 500th rubber duck icon (rubber). Listen, I get that crafting comes down to using base elements (Plastic, metal, rubber, etc) to create other things, but more thought needed to be put into this to make looting not feel like an absolute chore. Pacific Drive dares to ask, what if STALKER was in a car, and it was a bit reddit.

The Good:
The wish-brand zone itself is very well represented as a living breathing character, and the temu-procured anomalies are inventive and well realized. I was impressed that they've managed to make a game where your main obstacles are "passive" and environmental, yet also feel like both benevolent and malevolent actors in your environment. The car is fairly fun to drive and doesn't feel too "authentically" weighty nor like you're driving a bouncy castle.

The game is very much about preparing and preserving your car, which is essentially your character, and taking calculated risks vs reward. That, and the mystery of the zone itself is very compelling.

There will be moments where you stop the car and get out and stare at the wind in the trees in the rain and you'll notice in the corner of your eye that a petrified human silhouette resides there now where one did not reside before, that is compelling.

The Bad:
However, if STALKER has shown anything, it's at its best when it shuts up. Pacific Drive demonstrates this aptly. A lot of the fun of gradually unravelling what's happening yourself by context, is ruined by both characters talking over each other incessantly, and putting all the details in a big (highly unpleasant to use in-game appendix). This is theatre: plays do not have appendices, if you have to send me to the wiki to get the context, that's a failure to storytell. Even better, just don't tell me, I don't need to know, it's often better that way.

In a similar vein, the misremembered 1980s stranger things ghostbusters-reboot portland-vegan-bookstore thing it's doing with its aesthetic, I can kind of take or leave. I see what they were going for, I don't think they completely sell it. The game is trying very hard to pull a Portal, but it is not pulling off a Portal. It's not quite finding the narrow sliver between eerie and farcial.

I don't particularly care for some of mad-science aspect of the game's setting or aesthetic, I think a lot of it robs the player of feeling responsible for their own survival, ends up feeling more akin to magic than ingenuity, and exists more to justify the game's mechanics than for story reasons.

The Ugly:
Lastly, I'm sorry to say gentlemen, that this game has terminal rogueliteis. Many many games with great concepts and even partially great execution have fallen prey to the allure of "your potential adventures are unlimited", only for every adventure to feel like the same blended, grey porridge. Game feels a bit thin on complexity? Toss a few random status effects in there, slap it on the ass- she'll be right.

I would have preferred an eighth of the content presented to me a series of stops on a linear roadtrip, with more time to smell the roses and 400,000,000 fewer things to pick up. This is essentially an inventory tetris crafting game where the playable areas or "junctions" on the road are the rooms in the dungeon, and you can teleport home if you have enough of the game's rare-resource.

You can feel the hands of the designer artificially creating arbitary limitations to gate your progress and pad it out a bit more- hurrying you through to create a sense of artificial tension. I was disappointed that I couldn't pick a junction to explore and just drive there based on the routes on the map- under certain circumstances you'll just have no exits and you'll have to teleport home.

This essentially exists to make sure that you're returning to your base to recuperate and upgrade, picking up new story and building up to progressively longer runs rather than just driving as far as you can go. I generally try to refrain from being critical of a game for being "grindy" because it's reductive and passe- but it's very much at odds with the sense of mystery the game is trying to project.

You'll find that a lot of the "interesting choices" you're presented with gradually reveal themselves to be mandatory choices. Rather than taking in what you're seeing, you're gonna spend a lot of time anxiously looking at your inventory to ensure you got what you need before hitting a dead end and coming home- rather than being in the moment or choosing to be a pioneer and press on into the unknown. 

Also, performance is a bit ropey for how it looks, I think this is a probably an unreal engine thing more than a Pacific Drive thing. Sometimes the game is very pretty and very striking looking due to good stylistic choices and running fine- other times you'll be standing inside your garage wondering why your temps are a bit warm.

Pacific Drive boasts a really neat concept at first glance: a lonesome road trip through the haunted roads of a mysterious walled-off exclusion zone, where the player must evaluate their routes, scavenge for supplies and maintain their vehicle in order to achieve their goals and escape.

But once the game gets going the reality of what this game offers turns out to be something rather different. Pacific Drives gameplay quickly boils down into a fairly short and repetitive cycle. You spend an inordinately long time fixing up and maintaining your car in a garage, then drive off. You then drive for a distance so short you'd probably have made it faster on foot before having to dismount to explore and collect stuff, then hop into the car again, drive another short hop and repeat, repeat, repeat.

The act of turning the engine off, putting on the parking brake, opening the door, exiting the car, closing the door and doing all that again in reverse order is what most of the time in this game seems to be made up of. It gets tedious quickly and the rewards gained don't really make it all feel worthwhile.

The game tries to spice up its gameplay with obstacles and anomalies, unpredictable dangers to the players progress, but these also become known, repetitive and dull very quickly as it becomes clear the challenges are quite static and easily avoided. Sure, you'll get zapped or bumped from time to time to ensure you'll need to repair your car or replace a part, but it never really felt truly threatening as the difficulty level seems quite low by default.

Story and character mostly come via radio conversations you get to listen in on as the silent protagonist. Scientists who chose to stay inside the walled off Zone ramble off technobabble, bicker and argue and act shocked and surprised at every point of story progression, but their lack of direct involvement in anything makes what story and drama there is feel distant and hollow, the characters forced stereotypes crafted to fill out base archetypes.

While I did complete the game, it left me feeling quite disappointed and exhausted, and I can't really recommend Pacific Drive in the end. The game never cashes in the promise of a haunted road trip, but instead turns a fairly basic scavenging game into a tedious hassle with the inclusion of a car that feel unnecessary and tacked on, rather than feeling like the glorious centerpiece it should have been.

Pacific Drive dares to ask, what if STALKER was in a car, and it was a bit reddit.

The Good:
The wish-brand zone itself is very well represented as a living breathing character, and the temu-procured anomalies are inventive and well realized. I was impressed that they've managed to make a game where your main obstacles are "passive" and environmental, yet also feel like both benevolent and malevolent actors in your environment. The car is fairly fun to drive and doesn't feel too "authentically" weighty nor like you're driving a bouncy castle.

The game is very much about preparing and preserving your car, which is essentially your character, and taking calculated risks vs reward. That, and the mystery of the zone itself is very compelling.

There will be moments where you stop the car and get out and stare at the wind in the trees in the rain and you'll notice in the corner of your eye that a petrified human silhouette resides there now where one did not reside before, that is compelling.

The Bad:
However, if STALKER has shown anything, it's at its best when it shuts up. Pacific Drive demonstrates this aptly. A lot of the fun of gradually unravelling what's happening yourself by context, is ruined by both characters talking over each other incessantly, and putting all the details in a big (highly unpleasant to use in-game appendix). This is theatre: plays do not have appendices, if you have to send me to the wiki to get the context, that's a failure to storytell. Even better, just don't tell me, I don't need to know, it's often better that way.

In a similar vein, the misremembered 1980s stranger things ghostbusters-reboot portland-vegan-bookstore thing it's doing with its aesthetic, I can kind of take or leave. I see what they were going for, I don't think they completely sell it. The game is trying very hard to pull a Portal, but it is not pulling off a Portal. It's not quite finding the narrow sliver between eerie and farcial.

I don't particularly care for some of mad-science aspect of the game's setting or aesthetic, I think a lot of it robs the player of feeling responsible for their own survival, ends up feeling more akin to magic than ingenuity, and exists more to justify the game's mechanics than for story reasons.

The Ugly:
Lastly, I'm sorry to say gentlemen, that this game has terminal rogueliteis. Many many games with great concepts and even partially great execution have fallen prey to the allure of "your potential adventures are unlimited", only for every adventure to feel like the same blended, grey porridge. Game feels a bit thin on complexity? Toss a few random status effects in there, slap it on the ass- she'll be right.

I would have preferred an eighth of the content presented to me a series of stops on a linear roadtrip, with more time to smell the roses and 400,000,000 fewer things to pick up. This is essentially an inventory tetris crafting game where the playable areas or "junctions" on the road are the rooms in the dungeon, and you can teleport home if you have enough of the game's rare-resource.

You can feel the hands of the designer artificially creating arbitary limitations to gate your progress and pad it out a bit more- hurrying you through to create a sense of artificial tension. I was disappointed that I couldn't pick a junction to explore and just drive there based on the routes on the map- under certain circumstances you'll just have no exits and you'll have to teleport home.

This essentially exists to make sure that you're returning to your base to recuperate and upgrade, picking up new story and building up to progressively longer runs rather than just driving as far as you can go. I generally try to refrain from being critical of a game for being "grindy" because it's reductive and passe- but it's very much at odds with the sense of mystery the game is trying to project.

You'll find that a lot of the "interesting choices" you're presented with gradually reveal themselves to be mandatory choices. Rather than taking in what you're seeing, you're gonna spend a lot of time anxiously looking at your inventory to ensure you got what you need before hitting a dead end and coming home- rather than being in the moment or choosing to be a pioneer and press on into the unknown. 

Also, performance is a bit ropey for how it looks, I think this is a probably an unreal engine thing more than a Pacific Drive thing. Sometimes the game is very pretty and very striking looking due to good stylistic choices and running fine- other times you'll be standing inside your garage wondering why your temps are a bit warm.

Buy on sale.

I was expecting an atmospheric, narratively driven linear game about driving into the heart of a reality-distorting mystery zone. I thought I would be doing things like avoiding weird creatures and phenomena, have a group of NPCs on the radio leading me through the world and story, and a series of tense levels with some tense moments.

What I got was a very uninspired open world survival game... with no open world. To their credit, closed-world survival game is a new genre.

The gameplay loop is: go back to the garage, repair your car, pick a series of levels to drive through to whatever story objective you have. These levels are barren wastelands for the most part, and they aren't even procedurally generated (though I think the points of interest move around some, the map itself is static -- which causes all sorts of fun issues like an item that you have to pick up and return to your car while you take constant damage spawns two miles from the nearest road in a deep forest up steep cliffs your car can't handle). They're empty on purpose. Except of course for the junk and car parts you have to grind up for scrap metal to build... car parts. Did you bust a tire and want to take one from an abandoned car? Tough. Either grind it up for rubber and build a brand new wheel and tire on the "crafting mat" in the back of your car or use a tool that requires mid-game crafting materials that literally uses explosives to blow pieces off (and therefore, heavily damaging them). On a related note, for a Zone that supposedly causes technology to not work, there sure is a lot of working lights, televisions, and computers that you literally grind up for copper wire.

Oh, and progressing the story involves driving to a specific zone (and anywhere from 0-3 zones between them that are just time wasting since, again, no real threats exist). Then you do a thing there, have the standard garage reset, and have a new zone to go to, usually a stop or two beyond where you just were. But the devs made it so the zones you went through in the last run are wracked with instability and cause constant damage. So you're forced to do these completely unproductive baby runs just to be allowed to play the main game again.

The "anomalies" are almost entirely static, unmoving zones of either damage or radiation (aka different damage). How scary, I have to drive around them. The few mobile ones are, at worst, nuisances (with the exception of the Tourist, who you meet very early on, and I kid you not is the only good one). Like "I stole the item you were carrying and ran away 20 feet tee-hee" levels of little brother behavior. The biggest antagonists you have to face are how pitch black the game is at night and the hilly terrain. I died exactly once, because my car fell into a ditch I couldn't see while headed to the exit (which creates a battle-royale style shrinking circle). 

If the Zone is supposed to full of all these reality-warping effects, why the hell is each level an empty, normal forest (the second of three areas is mostly swamp with some glowy plants like Zangarmarsh in WoW or a biome called The Scorch which is like... The Scorch in Fallout 76). Shouldn't there be cool gouges in the land where reality torn a mountain in half? Bridges made of teeth across a forest of moving, carnivorous trees? Nope, just different color circles to stay out of. If you've played Too Human, it's almost exactly like that, but without enemies (note that I like that there's no guns or traditional combat in Pacific Drive, but that doesn't mean there should not be conflict or meaningful adversaries at all).

The story is like someone was told about Roadside Picnic (the same novel that inspired the movie and game Stalker, which are wildly different in their own right) then decided to make a game with the same premise 10 years later after they forgot everything interesting that happened. Naturally, the NPCs can talk to you on the radio, but you have no radio transmitter, so it's all one-sided, despite the fact you have direct access to all of them through the pneumatic tubes you send and receive mission items through. I guess the main character never learned how to write, or you could send notes that way.

True kudos to the voice actors though, they do a magnificent job turning a script with glaring plot holes (like a character telling us her motivation, only for the other characters to get mad at her for hiding her motivation -- WHAT?) and loads of filler dialogue into some enjoyable performances. But in 25 hours playing through the first two zones, there were maybe 3 actual points where the plot moved forward, and always in the most obvious way possible.

What a waste of a good premise.
